courses.subject: GISM
courses.title: Geographic Information Systems

meetings.instructor:
Dr. SHEA Yu Kai Geoffrey, 
Professor CHEN Yongqi

Dr. SHEA Yu Kai Geoffrey, 
Professor CHEN Yongqi

courses.description: This course discusses the principles, structure and application of geographic information systems. It emphasizes on the use of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to organize and manage spatial data, and how to perform spatial analysis with GIS. Topics include: GPS data acquisition, georelational data model, raster and vector data structures, spatial database, spatial analysis and application issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include: GPS data acquisition, georelational data model, raster and vector data structures, spatial database, spatial analysis and application issues.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Course and Teaching Evaluation

- Students are welcome to give comments and feedback during the class.
courses.required_readings:
* *Textbook** (reserved in Chung Chi Library)

Chang, Kang-tsung, 2016, Introduction to Geographic Information Systems, 8th Edition, McGrew Hill International Edition [[G70.212 .C4735 2016]](https://julac-cuhk.alma.exlibrisgroup.com/view/uresolver/852JULAC_CUHK/displayItems?physicalServicesResultId=13163617380003407&institutionCode=852JULAC_CUHK&userId=&skinName=cuhk_newui&leganto=false&newUI=true&mmsId=991034023959703407&holdingKey=HoldingResultKey+%5Bmid%3D22772577480003407%2C+libraryId%3D531586720003407%2C+locationCode%3Dul%2C+callNumber%3DG70.212+.C4735+2016%5D&description=&year=&volume=&expandholdingInfo=false&filterByView=false&displayRegisterToInstLink=false).

* *Major Reference Book** (reserved in Chung Chi Library)

Burrough, P. A., McDonnell, R., McDonnell, R. A., & Lloyd, C. D. (2015). Principles of geographical information systems. Oxford University Press. [G70.212 .B87]

courses.subject: GISM
courses.title: GIS-T and Logistical Information Management

meetings.instructor:
Professor HE Ying, 
Professor ZHENG Qiming

Professor HE Ying, 
Professor ZHENG Qiming

Professor HE Ying, 
Professor ZHENG Qiming

Professor HE Ying, 
Professor ZHENG Qiming

courses.description: This course focuses on how geographic information systems (GIS) can be used to support various applications in transportation and logistics. This course covers such topics as shortest paths, routing, network flows, facility location, travel demand analysis, and intelligent transportation systems. Students will use TransCAD (Caliper Corp.) and ArcGIS (ESRI) in this course to gain hands-on experience with GIS-T. The main course objective is to help students gain a better understanding of GIS-T concepts and GIS-T applications.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Introduction to GIS-T Sept 8

2+3 Network Representations

4+5 Shortest Path Problem

6 Linear Referencing Systems (LRS) and Dynamic segmentation

7 Location-Allocation Models

8 Network Flow Models

9 Transportation Planning

10 Activity-travel analysis

11 Transportation Demand Management
courses.required_readings:
Textbook
TransCAD User Guide by Caliper Corporation (Copies available in the lab.)
TransCAD Travel Demand Modeling User Guide by Caliper Corporation (Copies available in the lab.)
TransCAD Vehicle Routing and Logistics User Guide by Caliper Corporation (Copies available in the lab.)

courses.subject: GISM
courses.title: Digital Remote Sensing Image Analysis

meetings.instructor: Dr. WONG Kwan Kit
Dr. WONG Kwan Kit
Dr. WONG Kwan Kit
Dr. WONG Kwan Kit

courses.description: This course discusses the principles and applications of remote sensing image analysis. Topics include principle of remote sensing, acquisition of satellite imagery, format of digital images, digital image processing systems, image display, geometric correction, radiometric adjustment, image enhancement, image classification, accuracy verification, change detection, and orthophoto applications. This course is taught with both lectures and laboratories. Lectures will be accompanied by laboratories for students to grasp both the theoretical and practical issues in remote sensing image analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Principle of Remote Sensing
2) Image Resolutions
3) Technical Aspects of Resolutions
4) Image Enhancement
5) Image Preprocessing
6) Multispectral Transforms
7) Spatial Filtering and Texture Analysis
8) Image Classification
9) Accuracy Assessment
10) Change Detection
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Students’ reaction during the lecture
• Students’ feedback and suggestion from Blackboard forum
• Informal interaction with students and tutors
• Student performance in the class and examination
• Previous course evaluation results
courses.required_readings: Jensen, J.R., 2005, Introductory Digital Image Processing: A Remote Sensing Perspective, 3rd edition, Prentice-Hall, Upper Saddle River, New Jersey.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Jensen, J.R., 2016, Introductory Digital Image Processing: A Remote Sensing Perspective, 4th edition, Pearson Education, Inc. Glenview, IL
• Campbell, J.B., 2002, Introduction to Remote Sensing, 3rd edition, Guilford, New York.
• Fenstermaker, L.K., 1994 (ed.), Remote Sensing Thematic Accuracy Assessment: A Compendium, American Society for Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing, Nethesda.
• Franklin, S. 2001, Remote Sensing for Sustainable Forest Management, Lewis, Boca Raton.
• Jensen, J.R., 2007, Remote Sensing of the Environment, an Earth Resource Perspective, 2nd edition, Prentice Hall, New York.
• Lillesand, T.M., R.W. Kiefer and J.W. Chipman, 2008, Remote Sensing and Image Interpretation, 6th edition, John Wiley and Son, Hoboken, NJ.
• Mather, P.M., 2004, Computer Processing of Remotely Sensed Images, 3rd edition, John Wiley & Sons, New York.
• Richards, J.A. and X. Jia, 2006, Remote Sensing Digital Image Analysis, 4th edition, Springer & Verlag, London.
• Schott, J.R., 1997, Remote Sensing: the Image Chain Approach, Oxford University Press, New York.
• Schowengerdt, R.A., 2007, Remote Sensing: Models and Methods for Image Processing, 3rd Edition, Academic Press, New York.
• Wilkie, D.S., 1996, Remote Sensing Imagery for Natural Resources Monitoring: A Guide for First-Time Users, Columbia University Press, New York.

courses.subject: GISM
courses.title: Applied Remote Sensing

meetings.instructor: Dr. WONG Kwan Kit
Dr. WONG Kwan Kit
Dr. WONG Kwan Kit
Dr. WONG Kwan Kit

courses.description: This course discusses various applications of remote sensing image analysis. The course begins by introducing the basic principle of remote sensing and an overview of remote sensing applications. On one hand, individual topics covering the application of remote sensing in vegetation, urban landscape, water and hydrology are discussed. On the other hand, various kinds of remotely-sensed data including high-resolution, thermal, hyperspectral, radar are introduced. This course is taught with lectures, laboratories and individual projects. Lectures will be accompanied by laboratories for students to grasp both the theoretical and application issues of remote sensing. Students are required to initiate, present and submit individual project to complete the course requirement.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Principle of radiative transfer

2) Image spectrometry

3) Thermal infrared remote sensing and applications

4) Radar remote sensing and applications

5) Airborne remote sensing

6) Advanced vegetation mapping/ classification

7) Vegetation biophysical parameter estimation

8) Water remote sensing and hydrological applications

9) Image fusion and feature selection

10) Advanced classification algorithms
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Students’ reaction during the lecture

• Students’ feedback and suggestion from Blackboard forum

• Informal interaction with students and tutors

• Student performance in the class and examination

• Previous course evaluation results

• Jensen, J.R. (2004) Introductory Digital Image Processing: A Remote Sensing Perspective, 3rd edition, Prentice-Hall, Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey.

• Liang, h., X. Li and J. Wang (2012) Advanced remote sensing: terrestrial information extraction and applications, Elsevier/Academic Press, Waltham, MA.

• Lillesand, T.M., R.W. Kiefer and J.W. Chipman (2008) Remote Sensing and Image Interpretation, 6th edition, John Wiley and Son, Hoboken, NJ.

• Wilkie, D.S. (1996) Remote Sensing Imagery for Natural Resources Monitoring: A Guide for First-Time Users, Columbia University Press, New York.

courses.subject: GISM
courses.title: Global Positioning Systems
courses.description: This course covers the basic principles of Global Positioning Systems (GPS): observables, error sources and their reduction, and positioning techniques. Other systems of Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) will also be introduced. Applications of GNSS in various fields will be discussed, including navigation, Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS), Location Based Services (LBS), engineering, and atmosphere sensing. Through hands-on exercises, students will learn how to use GPS devices to collect data in the field in support of various geospatial applications.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.course_syllabus:
L1: GPS/GNSS: the concept

L2: GPS observables

L3: Coordinate/time systems

L4: Positioning with pseudo-ranges

L5: Positioning with carrier phases

L6: RTK and precise point positioning (PPP)

L7 & 8: GPS Applications in navigation &LBS

L9: GPS Applications in engineering

L10: GPS Applications in atmosphere sensing

L11: GPS modernization & other GNSS systems
courses.required_readings:
* Ahmed El-Rabbany, Introduction to GPS - The Global Positioning System, Artech House 2002. [G109.5 .E6 2002](http://library.cuhk.edu.hk/search/cG109.5+.E6+2002/cg+++109.5+e6+2002/-5,-1,,E/browse)

courses.subject: GISM
courses.title: Artificial Intelligence for Smart Cities

meetings.instructor:
Dr. WONG Kin Hong, 
Professor LEUNG Yee

Dr. WONG Kin Hong, 
Professor LEUNG Yee

Dr. WONG Kin Hong, 
Professor LEUNG Yee

Dr. WONG Kin Hong, 
Professor LEUNG Yee

Dr. WONG Kin Hong, 
Professor LEUNG Yee

Dr. WONG Kin Hong, 
Professor LEUNG Yee

courses.description: This course aims at the concepts and applications of artificial intelligence in solving real-life problems in Smart-City management. Fundamentals of artificial intelligence methods for decision making will be discussed. It covers various paradigms for artificial-intelligence applications in spatial knowledge representation and inference, computational models and intelligent spatial decision support systems (SDSS). The enrichment of spatial decision support by data mining and knowledge discovery will also be examined. Open-source artificial intelligence software systems will be introduced to facilitate discussions, and to assist students to acquire hands-on experience of the relevant knowledge.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introduction to Decision Making and Decision Support
* Introduction to Smart-City design
* Symbolic Approaches to Spatial Knowledge Representation and Inference
* Expert Systems and Fuzzy Logic
* Fuzzy Expert System and Shells
* Fundamentals of Fuzzy Query
* Modern Neural Network Models and Applications
* Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)
* Recursive Neural Network (RNN)
* Neural object detection methods
* Ensemble methods for machine learning
* Data classification using decision tree
* Fully Integrated SDSS
courses.feedback_evaluation:
In order to improve the teaching and learning quality for this course, the following feedback mechanisms are implemented.

| Feedback | To whom | Where | When |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Qualitative feedback from students/discussion forums | Tutors and/or teachers through informal interaction | During lecture and outside class | Throughout the term |
| Course evaluation | Teachers and department | Lecture room | End of the term |
| Visiting examiner report | University, department and teachers | Overseas | End of the term |
| Reflection of teachers (including evidence from assessment) | Teachers and tutors | All learning activities | Throughout the term |
| Curriculum review | Related teachers and Curriculum & Teaching Committee | Department | End of the term |
courses.required_readings:
* Arbib, M.A. (ed.). *The Handbook of Brain Theory and Neural Networks*. Cambridge: MIT, 1995.
* Giarratano, J. and G. Riley. *Expert Systems: Principles and Programming*. Boston: PWS-KENT, 1998.
* Goodfellow I., Y. Bengio and A. Courville. *Deep Learning*. Cambridge: MIT Press, 2016.
* Han, J. and M. Kamber. *Data Mining: Concepts and Techniques*. San Francisco: Morgan Kaufmann Publishers, 2001.
* Jackson, P. *Introduction to Expert Systems*. Reading: Addison-Wesley, 1990.
* Leung, Y. *Intelligent Spatial Decision Support Systems*. Berlin: Springer-Verlag. 1997.
* Leung, Y. *Knowledge Discovery in Spatial Data*. Berlin: Springer-Verlag. 2010.
* Miller, H.J. and J. Han (eds.). *Geographic Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery*. London: Taylor & Francis, 2001.
* Negotia, C. V. *Expert Systems and Fuzzy Systems*. California: Benjamin/Cummings, 1985.
* Rashid, Tariq. *Make your own neural network*. CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform, 2016.
* Rich, E. and K. Knight. *Artificial Intelligence*. New York: McGraw-Hill, 1991.
* Sergios Theodoridis. *Machine Learning : A Bayesian and Optimization Perspective* 2nd edition, 2020, Academic press
* Turban, E. *Decision Support and Expert Systems: Management Support Systems*. New York: Macmillan, 1993.
* Turban, E. *Expert Systems and Applied Artificial Intelligence*. N.Y.: Macmillan, 1992.
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the list above.

courses.subject: GISM
courses.title: Urban Environmental Modeling and Simulation

meetings.instructor:
Professor LAM Kin Che, 
Professor MA Peifeng

Professor LAM Kin Che, 
Professor MA Peifeng

Professor LAM Kin Che, 
Professor MA Peifeng

Professor LAM Kin Che, 
Professor MA Peifeng

Professor LAM Kin Che, 
Professor MA Peifeng

Professor LAM Kin Che, 
Professor MA Peifeng

courses.description: This course covers major concepts and methods for modeling spatial patterns and processes. Topics include cellular automata, agent-based models, terrain modeling, spatio-temporal data modeling, integration of GIS and environmental modeling, noise modeling, modeling of watershed hydrology and water quality and other relevant applications. During the course, students will learn about different modeling approaches and their applications and work on lab exercises and course projects.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.course_syllabus:
* Overview of modeling and simulation
* Surface modeling
* Cellular automata
* Agent-based modeling
* Noise – Basics and characterization
* Noise – Propagation and modeling
* GIS-based noise mapping
* GIS-assisted noise planning
* Hydrologic and water quality simulation using watershed models: Historical development and new challenges
* Hydrologic processes and simulation
* SCS Curve Number technique for hydrologic assessment of urbanization
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Student feedbacks will be obtained through:
- A simple questionnaire on the 3rd week of the course to obtain initial views from
students and for fine-tuning of the course
- Term-end course evaluation
- Discussion with students in the class and interactive tutorials
courses.required_readings:
There is no single text for this course. However, the following books and papers are given for reference:

* **GIS and Agent-based Modeling***

Gilbert, N. & K. G. Troitzsch, Simulation for the Social Scientist (2nd ed.), Open University Press, Berkshire, UK.

Batty, M. (1997). Cellular automata and urban form: A primer. *Journal of the American Planning Association*, 63(2): 266-275.

Brown, D. G., B. C. Pijanowski, et al. (2000). Modeling the relationships between land use and land cover on private lands in the Upper Midwest, USA. *Journal of Environmental Management*, 59(4): 247-263.

Brown, D. G., R. L. Riolo, et al. (2005). Spatial process and data models: Toward integration of agent-based models and GIS. *Journal of Geographical Systems*, 7(1): 1- 23.

Castle, E. J. & A. T. Crooks (2006). Principles and Concepts of Agent-Based Modeling for Developing Geospatial Simulations, retrieved from http://www.casa.ucl.ac.uk/ working\_papers/paper110.pdf

Huang, B. & C. Claramunt (2005). Spatiotemporal data model and query language for tracking land use change. *Transportation Research Record: Journal of the Transportation Research Board*, 1902: 107–113.

* **Noise Modeling***

King, E. A., E. Murphy & H. J. Rice (2011) Implementation of the EU environmental noise directive: Lessons from the first phase of strategic noise mapping and action planning in Ireland. *Journal of Environmental Management*, 92, 756-764.

Lam, K. C., W. Ma, P. K. Chan, W. C. Hui, K. L. Chung, Y.-T. T. Chung, C. Y. Wong & H. Lin (2013) Relationship between road traffic noisescape and urban form in Hong Kong, *Environmental Monitoring and Assessment*, 185 (12), 9683-9695.

Tsai, K.-T., M.-D. Lin & Y.-H. Chen (2009) Noise mapping in urban environments: a Taiwan study. *Applied Acoustics*, 70, 964-972.

* **Watershed Modeling***

Borah, D.K. and M. Bera (2003) Watershed-scale hydrologic and nonpoint-source pollution models: Review of mathematical bases. *Transactions of the ASAE*, 46(6): 1553-1566.

Chen, Y.D. (2000) Watershed modeling – where are we heading? In: Thurston, R.V. courses.subject: GISM
courses.title: Design and Implementation of Geographical Information Systems

meetings.instructor: Professor LIU Yan
Professor LIU Yan
Professor LIU Yan
Professor LIU Yan
Professor LIU Yan
Professor LIU Yan

courses.description: This course covers the basic principles for GIS design and application system implementation using the mainstream techniques. Topics include requirement analysis, object-oriented design using Unified Modeling Language (UML), database normalization, and GIS customization within a GIS environment. Students will develop their competence in designing and customizing GIS tools through lectures, hands-on lab exercises, and a course project.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.course_syllabus:
* SSADM
* Database design
* Python Programming Basics
* Python in geoprocessing
* Geodata management -- Cursor
* Geometric and File
* Work with Raster
* Selection and Query
* Custom tool and GUI
* Google Map API
* Web scrapping
* Machine Learning fundamental
* Deep Learning
* Neural Network
* Convolution Neural Network
courses.required_readings:
* *M****ajor Reference Book**

Zandbergen, P.A. (2013) PYTHON Scripting for ArcGIS, ESRI Press.

* *Internet Resources (online GIS study materials)**

Python videos:

<http://video.arcgis.com/series/82/python/order/asc>

ArcGIS help library: [http://resources.arcgis.com/en/help/main/10.1/index.html#/Welcome\_to\_the\_ArcGIS\_Help\_L](http://resources.arcgis.com/en/help/main/10.1/index.html%23/Welcome_to_the_ArcGIS_Help_Library/00qn0000001p000000/) [ibrary/00qn0000001p000000/](http://resources.arcgis.com/en/help/main/10.1/index.html%23/Welcome_to_the_ArcGIS_Help_Library/00qn0000001p000000/)

courses.subject: GISM
courses.title: Statistical Analysis of Geographical Data

meetings.instructor: Professor KAN Zihan
Professor KAN Zihan
Professor KAN Zihan
Professor KAN Zihan

courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the basic and spatial statistical analysis methods that are commonly used to investigate geographically represented data. Topics covered include: (1) correlation analysis, (2) principal components analysis, (3) cluster analysis, (4) Geostatistical analysis, and (5) global and local spatial regression models. Students will develop their competency in using and applying GIS and statistical tools to solve real-world geographical problems through hands-on lab exercises and course projects.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of this course, students are expected to:

• Understand the principles of basic statistics and spatial statistics,

• Develop proficiency in using GIS and statistical tools relevant to the principles covered, and

• Apply the knowledge to analyze real-world geographical problems
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Geographical data manipulation

2. Correlation and spatial autocorrelation analysis

3. Linear and stepwise regression analysis

4. Logistic regression analysis

5. Principal component analysis

6. Factor analysis

7. Canonical correlation analysis

8. Cluster analysis

9. Discriminant analysis

10. Spatial regression models

11. Geographically weighted regression analysis

12. Geostatistical Kriging models

13. Presentations by postgraduates
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• The suggestions and information from the early course evaluation

• Students’ reaction during the lectures

• Students’ feedback and suggestion from CU eLearning System

• Informal interaction with students and tutors

• Student performance in the class and examination

• Previous course evaluation results
courses.required_readings:
•Marcoulides George A. and Scott L. Hershberger (1997), Chapter 2 Basic Matrix Algebra, Multivariate Statistical Methods: A First Course, Mahwah: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, 9-22

•Griffith Daniel A. (2003), Spatial Autocorrelation and spatial Filtering: Gaining Understanding Through Theory and Scientific Visualization, Germany: Springer

•Hsieh Chun-Ying, Chou Kuo-Ping (2002), A spatial autocorrelation analysis of aging distribution and transition, Journal of Population Studies, Vol 25, pp, 91-119

•Kachigan Sam Kash (1991) Chapter 4 Regression analysis, Multivariate Statistical Analysis: A Conceptual Introduction, New York: Radius Press, 160-193

•Luc Anselin (2005), Exploring Spatial Data with GeoDaTM: A Workbook. URL: https://geodacenter.asu.edu/system/files/geodaworkbook.pdf

•Loo, Beckyp. Y. (2000), an application of canonical correlation analysis in regional science: the interrelationships between transport and development in China’s Zhujiang Delta, Journal of Regional Science, Vol 40, No. 1,

•Marcoulides George A. and Scott L. Hershberger (1997), Chapter 6 Canonical Correlation, Multivariate Statistical Methods: A First Course, Mahwah: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, 133-161

•Epperson Bryank, Li Tianquan (1996), Measurement of genetic structure within populations using Moren’s spatial autocorrelation statistics, Population Biology, Vol 93, pp. 10528-10532.
courses.recommended_readings:
•Anderson T.W. (2003), An Introduction to Multivariate Statistical Analysis, Third Edition, USA: Wiley Interscience

•Clifford Nicholas, Shaun French and Gill Valentine (eds) (2010), Key methods in geography, London : SAGE

•Goodchild Michael F. (1986), Spatial Autocorrelation, Norwich: Geo Books, Catmog 47

•Johnson, Richard A. & Dean W. Wichern (2002), Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis, Prentice-Hall, 5th edition

•Huang, B., Wu, B., and Barry, M., 2010. Geographically and Temporally Weighted Regression for modeling spatio-temporal variation in house prices. International Journal of Geographical Information Science, 24(3): 383 – 401.

•Huang, B., Zhang, L., and Wu, B., 2009. Spatio-temporal analysis of rural-urban land conversion. International Journal of Geographical Information Science, 23(3): 379 - 398.

•Johnston R.J. (1980), Multivariate Statistical Analysis in Geography, London: Longman Group Limited

•Kachigan Sam Kash (1991), Multivariate Statistical Analysis: A Conceptual Introduction,New York: Radius Press

•Marcoulides George A. and Scott L. Hershberger (1997), Multivariate Statistical Methods: A First Course, Mahwah: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates

•Wong David W.S. and Jay Lee (2005), Statistical Analysis of Geographic Information with ArcView GIS, New Jersey: John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

courses.subject: GISM
courses.title: Geospatial Big Data for Smart Urban Planning

meetings.instructor:
Dr. CAI Jixuan, 
Dr. Maria Del Mar FRANCESCH HUIDOBRO

Dr. CAI Jixuan, 
Dr. Maria Del Mar FRANCESCH HUIDOBRO

courses.description: This course introduces to students geospatial big data (e.g., social media and GPS trajectories) and their applications in urban planning, including land functionality classification, environmental monitoring, sentiment analysis, and transportation planning. The use of GIS in various urban applications relevant to big data will also be covered. These applications encompass urban form, public health, 3D GIS, and geodesign. Through hands-on lab exercises such as data crawling from the web, 3D urban model construction using CityEngine, and geodesign using Geoplanner, students are expected to understand how geospatial big data can be applied to address real-world challenges in the urban environment, and to grasp more advanced skills relating to GIS applications.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
• Understand the principles of urban planning, big data and 3D GIS.
• Develop proficiency in using advanced GIS tools relevant to big data, and
• Apply the knowledge to address real-world urban problems with the support of big data and GIS
courses.course_syllabus:
* Urban Planning theory and principle
* Town Planning in Hong Kong
* Overview of big data applications in urban planning
* Tutorial 1: Data collection and spatial processing using Python
* Tutorial 2: Re-projection, and data visualization
* Geotagged social media data
* Tutorial 3: Machine learning on spatial data analysis
* Big data for transportation applications
* Population distribution and urban environment assessment
* Urban form and Big Data
* Big tech giants’ dreams
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Students’ reaction during the lectures
* Discussion with students in the class and interactive tutorials
* Student performance in the class and examination
* Term-end course evaluation
courses.required_readings:
There is no single textbook for this class. The following materials are suggested for reference:

1. Levy, J. M. (2013). *Contemporary Urban Planning* (10th edition). Upper Saddle River: Prentice Hall.
2. Hall, P. and Tewdwr-Jones, M. (2011). *Urban and Regional Planning* (5th edition). London: Routledge.
3. Easa, S., and Chan.Y, (2000). *Urban Planning and Development Applications of GIS*. Reston, VA: American Society of Civil Engineers.
4. Karimi, H. A. (2014). *Big Data: Techniques and Technologies in Geoinformatics.* Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press.
5. Eldawy, A., & Mokbel, M. F. (2015, April). *The era of big spatial data*. In 2015 31st IEEE International Conference on Data Engineering Workshops (pp. 42-49). IEEE.
6. Li, S., Dragicevic, S., Castro, F. A., Sester, M., Winter, S., Coltekin, A., ... & Cheng, T. (2016). *Geospatial big data handling theory and methods: A review and research challenges*. ISPRS journal of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing, 115, 119-133.
7. Deng, X., Liu, P., Liu, X., Wang, R., Zhang, Y., He, J., & Yao, Y. (2019). *Geospatial big data: New paradigm of remote sensing applications*. IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing, 12(10), 3841-3851.
8. *A Science of Cities*, (personal website of Michael Batty, the founder of CASA) <http://www.complexcity.info/>
9. *Beijing City Lab*, <https://www.beijingcitylab.com/>
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the list above.

courses.title: Thesis

Professor KAN Zihan, 
Professor LAM Kin Che, 
Professor LEE Fung,

Professor MA Peifeng

courses.description:
The master thesis project is a compulsory course of the GISM program. It is not a regular course with modules and exercises, but an individual research project where you present your work in an oral presentation and a scientific written report.
Students are required to carry out independent studies of selected topics relevant to Geoinformation Science on a variety of problems under staff supervision. Evaluation is based on the oral presentation and written report.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Geoinformation Science
courses.required_readings: Relevant references will be provided when necessary.
